questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is accused of setting his neighbor’s house on fire and has been obsessed with becoming a firefighter since a young age and spends hours on the internet watching videos about fires and firefighting. Two years ago, he was caught setting a fire in his backyard. Based on this information, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyromania This child's fascination with fire and history of repetitive, intentional fire setting suggest a diagnosis of pyromania, a rare impulse control disorder more commonly found in males. Pyromania involves deliberate fire setting to relieve internal tension with no obvious motive (eg, profit, revenge, political statement, recognition).

Highyeild:

Individuals with this condition tend to be fascinated by fire and anything related to it (eg, fire stations, firefighters). They deliberately start fires to reduce tension and feel pleasure or relief afterward. Pyromania must be differentiated from a fire setting associated with a manic episode, psychosis, or substance intoxication.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder is given to individuals aged >18. It involves a pattern of violation of basic societal rules and the rights of others and requires a history of some symptoms of conduct disorder before age 15. Option: B. conduct disorder requires a persistent and pervasive pattern of violating major societal rules or the rights of others that includes additional problem behaviors (eg, aggression toward people and animals, deceitfulness, theft), which this patient does not exhibit Option: D. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood and defiant behavior toward authority This child's defiance of rules revolves around his fire setting, rather than being a pervasive pattern.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the OPD by his mothers with a history of stealing objects from friends and stores without their knowledge. The parents have had several awkward situations due to this behavior of the child. The child seems to be repeating it even after explanation and punishment by parents. A false statement about the disorder is

options.label: A
options.text: It may be associated with mental retardation

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms appear in times of significant stress

options.label: C
options.text: Onset is generally seen in childhood

options.label: D
options.text: The course of the disorder waxes and wanes

questions.correct_answer: C. Onset is generally seen in childhood
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Onset is generally seen in childhood This depicts Kleptomania, an impulse control disorder . The essential feature of kleptomania is a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or monetary value. The objects taken are often given away, returned surreptitiously, or kept and hidden. Persons with kleptomania usually have the money to pay for the objects they impulsively steal. As with other impulse-control disorders, kleptomania is characterized by mounting tension before the act, followed by gratification and lessening of tension with or without guilt, remorse, or depression after the act.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Brain diseases and mental retardation have been associated with kleptomania, as they have with other disorders of impulse Option: B. The symptoms of kleptomania tend to appear in times of significant stress, for example, losses, separations, and endings of important relationships. Option: D. The course of the disorder waxes and wanes, but tends to be chronic.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient, accompanied by her mother, reported hair loss for the past six months after a family conflict. The mother noted that, when the patient was nervous, she had an uncontrollable urge to manipulate the scalp, which intensified hair loss confirmed by the accumulation of hair around her. The psychiatrist diagnosed her with impulse control disorder. All of the following impulse control disorders except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dipsomania Dipsomania is an irresistible, typically periodic craving for alcoholic drinks . It is not classified under impulse control disorders .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect option:- Option B – Pyromania is an impulse control disorder characterized by pathological fire setting. Option C – Kleptomania is an impulse control disorder characterized by a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or their monetary value. Option D - Pathological gambling, an impulse control disorder characterized by compulsive gambling.

questions.text: A 20-year-old homeless man was admitted to a psychiatric unit after reports of fire-setting behavior (e.g., laughing while setting individuals on fire with lighter fluid). As a child, he had set fire to a hillside barn, which would have had significant consequences for a village further up the hill had it not been extinguished. Pathological fire-setting is also called:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyromania Pathological fire-setting, an impulse control disorder, is also called pyromania.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option B – Kleptomania is characterized by a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or their monetary value. Option C – Trichotillomania is characterized by compulsive hair pulling resulting in hair loss and balding. Option D - Dipsomania is an irresistible, typically periodic craving for alcoholic drinks.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presented with features of remaining aloof, and sad, having prominent guilt ideas, and entertaining thoughts of causing self-harm. While driving his motorcycle at night, he met with an accident and started to bleed profusely. He tasted his blood and liked the smell and taste of it. Thus, the frequent incidences of wrist cutting started so that he could suck his blood. Which drug is found to be effective in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbamazepine This patient is exhibiting intermittent explosive disorder . The t reatment of intermittent explosive disorder includes certain antidepressants ― specifically selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors ( SSRIs ) ― anticonvulsant mood stabilizers (carbamazepine in the options given).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – Haloperidol is indicated for use in psychotic disorders. Option B – Propranolol is a beta blocker indicated for use in anxiety disorders in conjunction. Option C – Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine indicated for use in those with anxiety disorders. It can be used in the patient above in conjunction with carbamazepine to treat his sleep problems.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, divorced male was remanded three times in the same year for the same charges and evaluated specifically with a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or their monetary value. Select one INCORRECT statement regarding this disorder:

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: In ICD-10, it is defined as repeated failures to resist impulses to steal objects that are not required for personal use or monetary gain.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more prevalent in males.

options.label: D
options.text: It often responds well to antidepressant medications, especially SSRIs such as fluoxetine.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is more prevalent in males.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is more prevalent in males. Pathological stealing/Kleptomania is more common in women than in men.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – CBT in conjunction with antidepressant medications is found to be effective for the management of pathological stealing. Option B – Kleptomania is defined as repeated failures to resist impulses to steal objects that are not required for personal use or monetary gain. Option D - Antidepressant medications, especially SSRIs are indicated in pathological stealing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old, divorced woman who had completed primary education and had various manual jobs, started shoplifting at the age of 30. She had multiple convictions of theft and several remand admissions. The acts of stealing were typically due to failure to resist the tension and a strong urge to take the items without paying, and feeling satisfied after taking them. The items typically were of no use to her. All of the following statements are TRUE regarding this except

options.label: B
options.text: It is more common in males

options.label: C
options.text: Patients with kleptomania experience anxiety before they steal

options.label: D
options.text: The disorder has a long course

questions.correct_answer: B. It is more common in males
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is more common in males Kleptomania is characterized by a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or their monetary value . It usually begins in early adolescence. It is more common in females than males (3:1).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – It is a rare disorder. The prevalence of kleptomania is between 3% and 0.6%. Option C - Patients with kleptomania do experience anxiety before they steal, and relief after doing so. Option D - The disorder may persist for years, even when patients face legal consequences.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was brought by her mother stating that her daughter, who is a salesperson, tends to get anxious easily and to unwind and let off steam, she shops in stores, online, and anywhere she can. For the most part, at first, she is excited about the shopping experience–and with her purchases. But once the initial thrill has passed, she starts to feel an increase of anxiety and self-loathing. Which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oniomania This patient exhibits compulsive buying behavior (CBB) , otherwise known as shopping addiction , pathological buying, or compulsive buying disorder. It is characterized by the persistent, excessive, impulsive, and uncontrollable purchase of products despite severe psychological, social, and occupational, financial consequences. Compulsive buying is also called oniomania .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Pyromania is pathological fire-setting. Option B - Kleptomania is pathological stealing. Option C - Trichotillomania is characterized by compulsive hair pulling.
